title: How to Take Care of Baby Platy Fish

steps.title: Be on the lookout for pregnant fish.
steps.content: Be on the lookout for pregnant fish. Pregnant platies are easy to spot, so if you keep a close eye on your fish, they shouldn't be a surprise. A pregnant platy will develop a noticeably swollen belly. They can also have an almost rectangular stomach as well when they are close to giving birth. It's also common for a pregnant female to develop a dark spot near her back fin. This is caused by the eyes of the unborn fry pressing against her scales.

steps.title: Ensure your tank is large enough.
steps.content: Ensure your tank is large enough. For a few adult platies, a 10 gallon tank is usually sufficient. However, if you plan for your platies to breed and you want to keep the fry, a much larger tank will be necessary. A minimum tank size of 29 gallons is recommended if you plan on letting your fish reproduce not letting them eat their fry.

steps.title: Consider a separate tank.
steps.content: Consider a separate tank. Because platies do eat their young, you will end up with the greatest number of surviving fry if you purchase a separate tank for them to live in while they grow. [2] X Research source A separate aquarium for your fry can be purchased at most pet stores. This tank should be at least 5 gallons (or more, depending on how many babies the mother produces).

steps.title: Purchase plants and/or a breeding trap.
steps.content: Purchase plants and/or a breeding trap. To survive, whether in a community tank or in a separate tank with only their mother, your fry will need hiding places to escape to. This purpose can be served by either a lot of plants or a breeding trap. [3] X Research source Plastic plants can be used, but live plants can often be a source of extra nutrition for your fish, who may take small bites of them to supplement their diets. [4] X Research source There are many types of live plants that platies enjoy, which should be available at your local pet store. Good choices include bunch plants, such as anacharis and cabomba, floating plants like hornwort and water sprite, and mosses such as java moss. [5] X Research source Many (but probably not all) of your platy fry will survive in a community tank if it contains enough plants for them to hide in. [6] X Research source A breeding trap is a plastic box with small holes that goes inside a fish tank. The mother is placed inside the breeding trap, and when the fry are born, they can escape through the small holes to avoid being eaten. The mother will not be able to follow them.

steps.title: Separate the mother from the community tank and wait.
steps.content: Separate the mother from the community tank and wait. If you've opted for a separate tank to keep the fry isolated from the adult fish, separate the mother as soon as you can after you've noticed she's pregnant. [7] X Research source You generally have between 24 and 30 days to make accommodations for your new fry once the mother shows signs of pregnancy. [8] X Research source Once the mother gives birth, you can expect to have 20-40 new fry on average. Sometimes, this number can climb as high as 80. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Return the mother to the community tank.
steps.content: Return the mother to the community tank. After the mother fish gives birth, you can return her to the community tank (assuming you separated her). The fry will now be free to develop without threat of being eaten.

steps.title: Feed the fry.
steps.content: Feed the fry. Baby platy fish do not require different food from adults. You can feed them the same pellets or flakes that you feed the adults, as well as freeze-dried bloodworms and tubifex, and brine shrimp. [10] X Research source Feed the fish small amounts several times a day, about as much food as they can eat in three minutes. [11] X Research source Some platy owners like to crush or grind pelleted or flaked food before feeding it to fry, as this will make it easier for them to eat. For platy fish to develop the brilliant colors that make them so beautiful, they must be fed a varied diet early in life, containing both protein and plant-based foods. [12] X Research source Specially formulated food is commercially available for platy fry, but is not necessary.

steps.title: Keep their tank clean.
steps.content: Keep their tank clean. Just as with your adult platies, you'll need to keep the tank for the fry clean. Changing 25 percent of the water at least every two weeks is typically adequate. [13] X Expert Source Craig Morton Fish & Aquarium Specialist Expert Interview. 21 July 2020. If the water becomes cloudy or full of debris, it should be changed more often.

steps.title: Introduce new fish into the community tank.
steps.content: Introduce new fish into the community tank. Once they have grown large enough to fend for themselves, you can move the young fish to the community tank with the older fish. Platy reach full size after about four months. If you decide to try to introduce them to the community tank sooner than that, keep an eye on them to make sure they aren't being eaten by the adults.
